es.title: Dialect: Latin America vs. Spain
es.content: The Spanish provided here leans towards Latin American usage. For example, 'Boleto' (Ticket) is used instead of the Spain-standard 'Billete'. However, it is understood perfectly everywhere.

es.title: The Ambiguity of "Ahorita"
es.content: You will hear 'Ahorita' (little now) constantly. Be warned: it is indefinite. It can mean 'right now', 'in 10 minutes', or 'eventually'. Context is key.

es.title: Social Manners: "Buen Provecho"
es.content: It is polite to say 'Buen provecho' (Enjoy your meal) when entering a restaurant or walking past someone who is eating. It is a standard courtesy.

es.title: Polite "What?"
es.content: In Mexico and parts of Latin America, saying '¿Qué?' (What?) can sound rude. It is much more polite to say '¿Mande?' (Command me?) or '¿Cómo?' when you didn't hear someone.

es.title: Getting the Bill
es.content: In many Spanish-speaking cultures, it is considered rude to bring the bill before it is requested (it implies rushing you). You must signal the waiter and ask for 'La cuenta'.

de.title: "Sonst noch etwas?"
de.content: You will hear this everywhere (bakeries, supermarkets). It is the standard way to ask if you are finished ordering.

de.title: Cash is King
de.content: Unlike the UK or Scandinavia, many smaller German shops and restaurants still do not accept cards. If you see 'Nur Barzahlung', it means Cash Only.

de.title: The Polite No
de.content: Germans are direct but polite. They often soften a refusal with the word 'Leider' (Unfortunately).

de.title: Sunday Quiet
de.content: Be aware that on Sundays (Ruhetag), almost all shops and supermarkets are closed. Restaurants usually remain open.

fr.title: The "Bonjour" Rule
fr.content: This is critical: You MUST say 'Bonjour' (or 'Bonsoir') immediately upon entering a shop. If you don't, you are considered invisible or rude, and service may suffer.

fr.title: "Avec ceci ?"
fr.content: Literally 'With this?', this is the standard phrase in every boulangerie or shop to ask if you want to buy more things.

fr.title: "Voilà"
fr.content: French people use this constantly when handing you something (a menu, your change, your coffee). It signifies the completion of an action.

fr.title: Water is Free
fr.content: You can always ask for a 'Carafe d'eau' (Jug of water) in a restaurant. It is tap water, perfectly safe, and free. 'Eau minérale' will cost you money.

it.title: "Nient'altro?"
it.content: In Italian delis or bars, they rarely ask 'Anything else?' Instead, they often ask 'Nothing else?' expecting a 'No' to confirm you are done.

it.title: "Ecco a lei"
it.content: The magic phrase of Italian service. You will hear it every time a waiter sets down a plate or gives you change. It roughly means 'Here is [item] for you.'

it.title: Coperto
it.content: Don't be surprised to see a 'Coperto' charge on your bill. It is a standard cover charge (usually €1-3 per person) for sitting down, bread, and silverware.

it.title: Coffee Rules
it.content: Cappuccino is strictly a breakfast drink. Ordering one after 11 AM (especially after a meal) identifies you immediately as a tourist.

ja.title: NO Tipping
ja.content: Tipping is not practiced in Japan and can be considered rude or confusing. The price is the price. If you leave money, they may run after you to return it.

ja.title: Take Out
ja.content: In Japan, they rarely say 'Take away.' You will likely be asked 'Tennai?' (Inside store) or 'Mochikaeri?' (Take home).

ja.title: The Indirect No
ja.content: Staff will almost never say the direct word 'Iie' (No). Instead, they use 'Moushiwake arimasen' (I have no excuse / I am terribly sorry).

ja.title: Customizing Food
ja.content: Use the suffix 'nuki' to remove an ingredient. For example, 'Wasabi-nuki' means 'Without Wasabi'.

pl.title: The Magic Word: "Proszę"
pl.content: This word is the WD-40 of Polish. It can mean: Please, Here you go, Go ahead, You're welcome, or Pardon me.

pl.title: Out of Stock
pl.content: Polish has a specific way of saying something is gone: 'Już nie ma' (literally: 'Already no have').

pl.title: Card Payments
pl.content: Poland is extremely digital. Paying 'Kartą' (With card) is standard almost everywhere, even for small amounts.

pl.title: "Chwileczkę"
pl.content: Poles use diminutives to be polite. Instead of 'Chwila' (Moment), they say 'Chwileczkę' (A tiny little moment) while making you wait.

pt.title: Multibanco
pt.content: In Portugal, you don't usually ask if they take 'card'. You ask for 'Multibanco', the specific name of their interbank network.

pt.title: Couvert
pt.content: In restaurants, waiters bring appetizers (olives, bread, cheese) automatically. These are NOT free. If you eat them, you pay for them. If you don't want them, just leave them untouched.

pt.title: Sold Out
pt.content: Similar to French, if a bakery runs out of items, they will simply say 'Acabou' (It ended).

pt.title: Ingredients
pt.content: When describing ingredients, Portuguese speakers often use the verb 'levar' (to take/carry). E.g., 'This dish takes peanuts.'

ru.title: Take Away
ru.content: The standard way to ask for takeaway is 'S soboy?' (literally: With self?).

ru.title: Sold Out
ru.content: Russians rarely say 'We don't have it.' They say 'Zakonchilos' (It ended).

ru.title: "Netu"
ru.content: While 'Net' means No, in casual speech you will often hear 'Netu' to mean 'There isn't any/We don't have any'.

ru.title: Waiting
ru.content: 'Minutochku' is a diminutive 'tiny little minute,' used to politely ask you to wait.

uk.title: "Proshu"
uk.content: A versatile word used when handing something over ('Here you go'), saying 'You're welcome,' or asking someone to repeat themselves.

uk.title: Cash Vocabulary
uk.content: Ukrainian uses 'Hotivka' for cash. If you see 'Lyshe hotivka', it means Cash Only.

uk.title: Take Away
uk.content: Like other Slavic languages, takeout is referred to as taking the food 'Z soboyu' (with yourself).

uk.title: Politeness
uk.content: Ukrainians value politeness. Using 'Bud laska' (Please) and 'Dyakuyu' (Thank you) frequently is expected.

zh.title: Scan Code
zh.content: Cash is rare. Waiters will often point a scanner at you and say 'Saoma?' (Scan code?) for WeChat Pay or Alipay.

zh.title: "Da bao"
zh.content: The universal phrase for 'Take away' or 'Pack up', whether ordering at a counter or boxing up leftovers.

zh.title: Money Slang
zh.content: While the currency is the Yuan, in spoken street language, everyone uses 'Kuai' (similar to 'Bucks').

zh.title: Sold Out
zh.content: 'Mai wan le' (Sold out) is definitive. You will hear this frequently for popular items.

zh.title: No Tipping
zh.content: Like Japan, tipping is not part of the culture in Mainland China. It is not expected in restaurants or taxis.
